data.fact: Banging your head against a wall for one hour burns 150 calories.
data.description: Alternatively, you can walk your dog for 45 minutes, which also burns 150 calories – and is much less painful.

data.fact: In Switzerland it is illegal to own just one guinea pig.
data.description: This is because guinea pigs are social animals, and they are considered victims of abuse if they are alone.

data.fact: Pteronophobia is the fear of being tickled by feathers.
data.description: It’s also a fear of feathers themselves. The word “ptero” is the Greek word for feather, and “phobia” is also Greek, meaning fear.

data.fact: Snakes can help predict earthquakes.
data.description: They can sense a coming earthquake from 75 miles away (121 km), up to five days before it happens.

data.fact: A flock of crows is known as a murder.
data.description: Some might say that a group of two crows is an attempted murder!

data.fact: The oldest “your mom” joke was discovered on a 3,500 year old Babylonian tablet.
data.description: It was discovered in Iraq in 1976, however since then the tablet has been lost, but the text remains preserved.

data.fact: So far, two diseases have successfully been eradicated: smallpox and rinderpest.
data.description: The last naturally occurring case of smallpox was diagnosed in October 1977, and the last case of rinderpest was diagnosed in 2001.

data.fact: 29th May is officially “Put a Pillow on Your Fridge Day”.
data.description: This strange holiday spans back to the early 1900’s, where families would place a piece of cloth in their larders.

data.fact: Cherophobia is an irrational fear of fun or happiness.
data.description: That’s one phobia I wouldn’t like to have… it would probably mean they would fear these fun facts!

data.fact: 7% of American adults believe that chocolate milk comes from brown cows.
data.description: I know 7% doesn’t sound like a lot, but that actually works out at 16.4 million American adults.

data.fact: If you lift a kangaroo’s tail off the ground it can’t hop.
data.description: Kangaroos use their tails for balance whilst hopping, so if you elevate their tail, they would have no balance and fall over.

data.fact: Bananas are curved because they grow towards the sun.
data.description: Bananas go through a process called “negative geotropism.” Instead of growing towards the ground, they start growing towards the sun.

data.fact: Billy goats urinate on their own heads to smell more attractive to females.
data.description: Billy goats, or bucks is the name given to male goats.

data.fact: The inventor of the Frisbee was cremated and made into a Frisbee after he died.
data.description: Walter Frederick Morrison invented the Frisbee in 1948, which was originally called the Pluto Platter.

data.fact: During your lifetime, you will produce enough saliva to fill two swimming pools.
data.description: An average human produces between 1 to 2 liters of saliva each day, which is a maximum of 730 liters per year.

data.fact: If Pinocchio says “My Nose Will Grow Now”, it would cause a paradox.
data.description: This is known as Pinocchio’s Paradox.

data.fact: Polar bears could eat as many as 86 penguins in a single sitting…
data.description: …If they didn’t live at opposite ends of the earth! Polar bears live in the arctic, whereas penguins usually live in Antarctica.

data.fact: King Henry VIII slept with a gigantic axe beside him.
data.description: This wasn’t the only lethal weapon he owned. King Henry VIII had a huge collection of weapons, which included 6,500 handguns.

data.fact: Movie trailers were originally shown after the movie, which is why they were called “trailers”.
data.description: The problem with the trailers showing after the film was that audience wouldn’t stay around to watch them, making the trailers rather ineffective.

data.fact: An eagle can kill a young deer and fly away with it.
data.description: Never underestimate an eagle!

data.fact: Heart attacks are more likely to happen on a Monday.
data.description: Okay this isn’t exactly a fun fact, but it is interesting! Heart attacks are increased by 20% on Monday’s.

data.fact: Tennis players are not allowed to swear when they are playing in Wimbledon.
data.description: Because of this, line judges have to learn curse words in every language so they know when a player has violated the rules.

data.fact: In 2017 more people were killed from injuries caused by taking a selfie than by shark attacks.
data.description: There was only 5 deaths due to shark attacks in 2017, which is lower than the average year.

data.fact: The top six foods that make your fart are beans, corn, bell peppers, cauliflower, cabbage and milk.
data.description: It’s probably best if you avoid eating any of these if you’re going on a date!

data.fact: There is a species of spider called the Hobo Spider.
data.description: Most bites from the Hobo Spider (Tegenaria agrestis) happen when the spider is accidentally crushed or squeezed by a human.

data.fact: A lion’s roar can be heard from 5 miles away.
data.description: To be more specific, a lion can roar as loud as 114 decibels, which is roughly 25 times louder than a gas-powered lawnmower.

data.fact: Saint Lucia is the only country in the world named after a woman.
data.description: Saint Lucia was discovered by the French after they were shipwrecked on the island.

data.fact: A baby spider is called a spiderling.
data.description: Spiders aren’t cute, but this name kind of is! Spiderling is the official name for immature spiders.

data.fact: The United States Navy has started using Xbox controllers for their periscopes.
data.description: You read that right – because the control stick for periscopes is so complicated, using Xbox controllers reduces the learning time from hours to minutes.

data.fact: The following can be read forward and backwards: Do geese see God?
data.description: This sentence is what is called a “palindrome.”

data.fact: A baby octopus is about the size of a flea when it is born.
data.description: You would think this would make them hard to spot, however since eggs are laid by the tens of thousands, it would be hard to miss a massive cluster of pea-sized octopuses!

data.fact: A sheep, a duck and a rooster were the first passengers in a hot air balloon.
data.description: You read that right – in 1783, the first hot air balloon was launched carrying a sheep, duck, and a rooster.

data.fact: In Uganda, around 48% of the population is under 15 years of age.
data.description: Of the 41 million inhabitants, nearly half of those are youths.

data.fact: The average male gets bored of a shopping trip after 26 minutes.
data.description: Meanwhile, women don’t get tired of shopping until around 2 hours!

data.fact: In the 16th Century, Arab women could initiate a divorce if their husbands didn’t pour coffee for them.
data.description: Today, this would be unheard of. But back then, coffee was an integral part of Turkish society. So much so, that it was “grounds” for divorce.

data.fact: Recycling one glass jar saves enough energy to watch television for 3 hours.
data.description: Yup, that’s how important recycling is!

data.fact: After the premiere of “16 and Pregnant,” teen pregnancy rates dropped.
data.description: MTV may not have the most wholesome programs, but after the premier of this show, teen pregnancy dropped by 5.7% within 18 months of the show airing.

data.fact: Approximately 10-20% of U.S. power outages are caused by squirrels.
data.description: Harmless and cute as they seem, these fuzzy little creatures aren’t as innocent as you think!

data.fact: Facebook, Instagram and Twitter are all banned in China.
data.description: Those aren’t the only ones either – over 8,000 domain names are blocked.

data.fact: 95% of people text things they could never say in person.
data.description: Are you guilty of this? I know I am.

data.fact: Honeybees can recognize human faces.
data.description: Whereas before it was thought that only large brained mammals could distinguish faces, but honeybees can do this as well!

data.fact: The Battle of Hastings didn’t take place in Hastings.
data.description: The famous Battle of Hastings actually took place 7 miles from Hastings in a town that is today known as Battle. Fitting, right?

data.fact: While trying to find a cure for AIDS, the Mayo Clinic made glow in the dark cats.
data.description: This is due to their use a specific protein that was fluorescent green.

data.fact: A swarm of 20,000 bees followed a car for two days because their queen was stuck inside.
data.description: When the car parked, the thousands of bees swarmed onto the car and had to be taken off by beekeepers.

data.fact: Nearly 3% of the ice in Antarctic glaciers is penguin urine.
data.description: Because the temperature in the Antarctic is well below zero, the urine can’t evaporate and just combines with the glaciers.

data.fact: Bob Dylan’s real name is Robert Zimmerman.
data.description: Yep, his full name is Robert Allen Zimmerman – he started going by Bob Dylan early on in his career for no real reason. Simply because he wanted to!

data.fact: A crocodile can’t poke its tongue out.
data.description: Because their tongues are attached to the roof of their mouths, crocodiles cannot stick their tongues out – although their very similar counterparts, alligators, can.

data.fact: Sea otters hold hands when they sleep so they don’t drift away from each other.
data.description: This is a method mostly used by a mother and her pup to prevent them from separating.

data.fact: A small child could swim through the veins of a blue whale.
data.description: If you consider how large a blue whale’s heart is the size of a small car, it’s no surprise that a small child, around 3-4 years old, could swim through the massive veins of a blue whale.

data.fact: Bin Laden’s death was announced on 1st May 2011. Hitler’s death was announced on 1st May 1945.
data.description: Both of these cruel leader’s deaths were announced on the same day, but due to the time difference, Bin Laden actually died on May 2nd.

data.fact: J.K. Rowling chose the unusual name ‘Hermione’ so young girls wouldn’t be teased for being nerdy.
data.description: The name Hermione came from Shakespeare’s “A Winter’s Tale.”

data.fact: Hewlett-Packard’s (also known as HP) name was decided in a coin toss in 1939.
data.description: The name was always going to be a hyphenation of the two founders last names, so in order to decide between Hewlett-Packard and Packard-Hewlett, they flipped a coin.

data.fact: There is a total of 1,710 steps in the Eiffel Tower.
data.description: Standing 108 stories tall, there are 1,710 steps to get to the top of the Eiffel Tower.

data.fact: The Pokémon Hitmonlee and Hitmonchan are based off of Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan.
data.description: The third Pokemon of the Hitmons is also named after a martial artist.

data.fact: A woman tried to commit suicide by jumping off the Empire State Building. She jumped from the 86th floor but was blown back onto the 85th floor by a gust of wind.
data.description: Standing almost 1,500 feet tall, there’s no way anyone could survive that fall.

data.fact: Pirates wore earrings because they believed it improved their eyesight.
data.description: Along with many other reasons! Due to superstitions, they thought it protected them from bad eyesight (or even blindness), seasickness, and drowning.

data.fact: Los Angeles’s full name is “El Pueblo de Nuestra Senora la Reina de los Angeles de Porciuncula.”
data.description: The original name was quite a mouthful. It translates to “town of our lady the Queen of Angels of the River Porciuncula.”

data.fact: The Twitter bird actually has a name – Larry.
data.description: The name comes from Larry Bird, who is a famous Hall of Fame basketball player.

data.fact: Octopuses have four pairs of arms.
data.description: The six of an octopus’ tentacles serve as arms, while the other two are their “legs.”

data.fact: In the popular sitcom, Parks and Recreation, the writers had no idea Nick Offerman was a talented saxophone player when they wrote the Duke Silver plot line.
data.description: Nick Offerman has played the saxophone his whole life, so when the writer wrote about his character being a secret jazz musician, the coincidence was perfect.

data.fact: It snowed in the Sahara desert for 30 minutes on the 18th February 1979.
data.description: So far, this is the only known time in history that it snowed in the Sahara!

data.fact: Mike Tyson once offered a zoo attendant 10,000 dollars to let him fight a gorilla.
data.description: As it is, Tyson bribed a worker to open the zoo for just he and his wife to see the animals.

data.fact: ABBA turned down 1 billion dollars to do a reunion tour.
data.description: In 2000, ABBA was offered $1 billion dollars to reunite for 100 shows – which would have been $250 million per member.

data.fact: There has never been a verified snow leopard attack on a human being.
data.description: Unlike many other big cats, snow leopards are not aggressive towards humans.

data.fact: The first alarm clock could only ring at 4 a.m.
data.description: Invented in 1787, Levi Hutchins needed a way to wake up in time for work, so he made the alarm clock.

data.fact: Birds don’t urinate.
data.description: Contrary to what most mammals do, birds convert nitrogen to uric acid.

data.fact: Dying is illegal in the Houses of Parliaments.
data.description: Strange as it is, this law is in place because anyone who dies in the Houses of Parliaments is entitled to a state funeral.

data.fact: The most venomous jellyfish in the world is the Irukandji.
data.description: While it’s not the most deadly jellyfish, it is number two!

data.fact: The 20th of March is Snowman Burning Day.
data.description: This strange holiday was spawned by American and Swiss citizens to symbolize the end of the winter season.

data.fact: Queen Elizabeth can’t sit on the Iron Throne from Game of Thrones.
data.description: Queen Elizabeth visited the set of Game of Thrones, but because of an obscure rule, she wasn’t allowed to sit on it – the ruling monarch can’t sit on a foreign throne, even if it’s fictional, apparently.

data.fact: There is official Wizard of New Zealand.
data.description: In 1990, the Prime Minister of New Zealand appointed Ian Brackenbury Channell, who was an old friend, as the Wizard of New Zealand. He is even given an annual stipend.

data.fact: An apple, potato, and onion all taste the same if you eat them with your nose plugged.
data.description: Our sense of taste is 80% made up of our sense of smell.

data.fact: Vincent van Gogh only sold one painting in his lifetime.
data.description: Just a few months before his death, Van Gogh sold his painting “The Red Vineyard.”

data.fact: A company in Taiwan makes dinnerware out of wheat, so you can eat your plate!
data.description: Not only do they make plates out of wheat, but spoons, bowls, and chopsticks as well.

data.fact: The average person walks the equivalent of five times around the world in their lifetime.
data.description: Assuming the average person lives until they’re 80, they will walk about 110,000 miles in their lifetime.

data.fact: Michael Jackson offered to make a Harry Potter musical, but J.K. Rowling rejected the idea.
data.description: Rowling defended herself because she says she turned down a lot of adaption opportunities, and Michael Jackson’s just so happened to be one of them.

data.fact: The world record for stuffing drinking straws into your mouth at once is 459.
data.description: Manoj Kumar Maharana, from India, broke the world record on 28th August 2017 for stuffing 459 drinking straws in his mouth at once!

data.fact: Nutella was invented during WWII, when hazelnuts were mixed into chocolate to extend chocolate rations.
data.description: In an effort to extend his chocolate rations during World War Two, an Italian pastry maker mixed hazelnuts into chocolate.

data.fact: In 2011, more than 1 in 3 divorce filings in the U.S. contained the word “Facebook.”
data.description: References to social networks are on the rise when it comes to divorce cases, as well as child custody cases.

data.fact: According to Genesis 1:20-22 the chicken came before the egg.
data.description: Depending on your beliefs, these Genesis verses state that God created birds – not eggs that would hatch into birds. This includes chickens!

data.fact: Honeybees can get drunk on fermented tree sap.
data.description: It affects bees in a similar way that alcohol affects humans, causing flying accidents and making it difficult to get back to the hive.

data.fact: Tears contain a natural pain killer which reduces pain and improves your mood.
data.description: It’s actually an endorphin, which is why you can tend to feel better after a good cry!

data.fact: Squirrels forget where they hide about half of their nuts.
data.description: While not all squirrels bury their nuts, the ones that do only recover around 26% of their nuts.

data.fact: Millions of birds a year die from smashing into windows in the U.S. alone.
data.description: The actual number is somewhere between 365 million and 988 million!

data.fact: Dolly Parton lost in a Dolly Parton look-alike contest.
data.description: Dolly Parton entered a Dolly Parton themed drag queen contest, did her hair and makeup more dramatically, and not only lost, but received the least applause.

data.fact: George W. Bush was once a cheerleader.
data.description: Bush was a cheerleader in High School, and continued to be one while he attended Yale.

data.fact: In total, there are 205 bones in the skeleton of a horse.
data.description: Even though they are much greater in size to humans (we have 206), horses have just about the same number of bones in their skeleton as we do!

data.fact: Coca-Cola owns all website URLs that can be read as ahh, all the way up to 62 h’s.
data.description: A 2013 digital campaign by Coca-Cola spurred the company to purchase all 62 URL’s.

data.fact: Each year there are more than 40,000 toilet related injuries in the United States.
data.description: Some of these make sense, like a child of infant falling in.

data.fact: Strawberries can be red, yellow, green or white.
data.description: This of course refers to the different maturity stages of a strawberry.

data.fact: Mewtwo is a clone of the Pokémon Mew, yet it comes before Mew in the Pokédex.
data.description: Because Mewtwo was in the Pokémon game, but Mew was only acquired through events at the time, Mewtwo was given the number 150, while Mew is number 151.

data.fact: Four people lived in a home for 6 months infested with about 2,000 brown recluse spiders, but none of them were harmed.
data.description: While the brown recluse is one of three spiders in North America with venom that requires medical treatment, they are hardly ever aggressive.

data.fact: Madonna suffers from brontophobia, which is the fear of thunder.
data.description: This scary sounding word isn’t so complicated – it’s the fear of thunder.

data.fact: In June 2017, the Facebook community reached 2 billion active users.
data.description: Meaning, more than a quarter of the world’s population uses this popular social media outlet!

data.fact: Samuel L. Jackson requested to have a purple lightsaber in Star Wars in order for him to accept the part as Mace Windu.
data.description: Jackson wanted to be able to find himself on screen in big fight scenes, so he managed to get George Lucas to approve his request.

data.fact: Paraskavedekatriaphobia is the fear of Friday the 13th.
data.description: A few famous people are stricken with this absurd phobia, such as Franklin Roosevelt, and surprisingly enough, Stephen King.

data.fact: Kleenex tissues were originally used as filters in gas masks.
data.description: They were originally been developed as crepe paper and used for gas mask filters.

data.fact: In 1998, Sony accidentally sold 700,000 camcorders that had the technology to see through people’s clothes.
data.description: These cameras had special lenses that use infrared light meant to be used as night vision, but it also allowed you to see through some types of clothing.

data.fact: During your lifetime, you will spend around thirty-eight days brushing your teeth.
data.description: This equals out to about 35.5 days in total.

data.fact: Ronald McDonald is “Donald McDonald” in Japan because it makes pronunciation easier for the Japanese.
data.description: Ever since the first McDonald’s opened in Japan in 1971, the mascot has been called Donald McDonald.
